facts.text: Appellant was elected to the Legislative Assembly, Vindhya Pradesh, from Laundi Constituency.

Election Tribunal, Nowgong, set aside the appellant's election on grounds: (1) employed Government servants as polling agents, committing corrupt practice under Section 123(8) of Act 43 of 1951; (2) subsisting contracts between appellant and Vindhya Pradesh Government for printing electoral rolls, disqualifying under Section 17 of Act 49 of 1951.
Evidence of P.W. 5, if accepted, shows polling agent also did canvassing work for appellant.
No finding by Tribunal on whether polling agent did canvassing work; decision rested merely on appointment of Government servants as polling agents.
Tribunal found contracts subsisting between appellant and Vindhya Pradesh Government for printing electoral rolls.
Exhibit A-4 is copy of letter sent by appellant to Secretary to the Chief Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh, showing Vindhya Pradesh Government settled terms of contract and made payments thereunder.

legal_issues.text: Whether appointment of Government servant as polling agent per se constitutes corrupt practice under Section 123(8) of Act 43 of 1951, or requires canvassing work.

Whether contracts for printing electoral rolls were with Election Commission or with Vindhya Pradesh Government/Chief Commissioner, disqualifying appellant under Section 17 of Act 49 of 1951 read with Section 7(d) of Act 43 of 1951.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appointment of Government servant as polling agent does not per se fall within mischief of Section 123(8).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Satya Dev Busheri v. Padam Dev (A and S.B.)

petitioner_arguments.text: Contract for printing electoral rolls entered into with Election Commission, not State or Union Government.

respondent_arguments.text: Evidence of P.W. 5 shows polling agent did canvassing work, constituting corrupt practice under Section 123(8).

court_reasoning.text: Appointment of Government servant as polling agent does not per se fall within Section 123(8); no finding by Tribunal on canvassing, so no contravention.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Following Satya Dev Busheri v. Padam Dev

court_reasoning.text: Contracts with Chief Commissioner in Part C States operate as disqualification under Section 17 of Act 49 of 1951 read with Section 7(d) of Act 43 of 1951.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Preparation of electoral rolls distinct from printing; Tribunal finding that Vindhya Pradesh Government got rolls printed; Exhibit A-4 shows Government settled terms and made payments.

holdings.text: No contravention of Section 123(8) by appellant.
Contracts with Vindhya Pradesh Government/Chief Commissioner disqualify under Section 17 of Act 49 of 1951 read with Section 7(d) of Act 43 of 1951.

precedents_cited.case_name: Satya Dev Busheri v. Padam Dev
precedents_cited.relevance: Appointment of Government servant as polling agent not per se corrupt practice u/s 123(8); contracts with Chief Commissioner disqualify

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951 (Act 43 of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Corrupt practice of employing government servants; disqualification linkage

statutes_cited.name: Act 49 of 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Disqualification due to subsisting government contracts

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Superintendence of electoral rolls by Election Commission argued but distinguished from printing contracts

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed on first ground (no corrupt practice u/s 123(8)); second ground upheld (disqualification due to contracts with Vindhya Pradesh Government).

key_quotes.text: the appointment of a Government servant as polling agent does number per se tall within the mischief of Section 123(8).
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: companytracts with the Chief Commissioner in Part C States would operate as a disqualification for election to the State Legislatures under Section 17 of Act 49 of 1951 read along with Section 7(d) of Act 43 of 1951.
key_quotes.speaker: court
